Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was counting the last stack of bills at the register. It was almost closing time, and the drawer was full of large bills from a busy day. I glanced at the screen—my friend had texted, “Ugh, today was endless. I need to vent. Can you talk?” I knew she’d had a rough week, and I wanted to be there for her, to listen and let her unload. But my hands were trembling as I tried to focus on the numbers in front of me. If I made a mistake now, it could mean hours of paperwork and a stern talk from my manager. My friend expected me to be present, to care, to respond right away. My job demanded my full attention, precision, and speed. I could feel the pressure building inside me, torn between the urge to support my friend and the responsibility to finish my shift without error. My heart raced as I stared at the phone, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more in that moment.
